questions.text: Which hormone does not play a significant role in inutero growth of a fetus?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Growth hormone:

 

  • Despite being present in high levels in the fetus, growth hormone is not recognized for significantly influencing fetal growth.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B & D: Insulin, thyroid hormone, and cortisol play important roles in the inutero growth of a fetus.

questions.text: IV irritants were given as a result bradycardia,hypotension and apnea was developed. This represents which one of the following reflexes?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Bezold-Jarisch reflex: 

  • This is the correct answer. The Bezold-Jarisch reflex is a triad of responses (hypotension, bradycardia, and apnea) that can occur when certain types of intravenous drugs, known as 'irritants', are administered. This reflex is mediated by the activation of certain types of sensory nerve endings, known as chemoreceptors or mechanoreceptors, in the heart and lungs.

Incorrect Options: 

Option B - Bainbridge reflex: The Bainbridge reflex is a physiological reflex that increases heart rate when venous return to the heart increases. It does not typically result in a triad of hypotension, bradycardia, and apnea.

Option C - Cushing reflex: The Cushing reflex is a physiological nervous system response to increased intracranial pressure that results in Cushing's triad of increased blood pressure, irregular or decreased respirations, and bradycardia. It is not typically associated with the administration of intravenous irritants.

Option D - None of them: This is not the correct answer, as the Bezold-Jarisch reflex is the reflex that most closely fits the description given.

questions.text: A 7-month-old child was brought by her mother with complaints of diarrhoea and mucocutaneous lesions, as shown in the image. The symptoms have been present since weaning was started. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B- Acrodermatitis enteropathica

Explanation:

  • The patient's presentation with diarrhea and mucocutaneous lesions, which started since weaning is suggestive of a zinc deficiency disorder called as acrodermatitis enteropathica.
  • This rare autosomal recessive condition occurs due to impaired zinc absorption from a defective ZIP4 protein, typically becoming apparent when breast milk (naturally rich in bioavailable zinc) is replaced with solid foods.
  • Acrodermatitis Enteropathica:

 

  • Autosomal recessive disorder.
  • Severe zinc deficiency due to impaired intestinal absorption (ZIP4 protein defect).
  • Early infancy onset: Vesiculobullous, dry, scaly skin lesions (periorificial, buttocks, acral areas).
  • Associated with alopecia, eye changes, chronic diarrhea, growth retardation, and stomatitis.
  • Treatment: 2-3 mg/kg/day oral zinc therapy.

Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome (Option A): This primary immunodeficiency presents with the classic triad of recurrent infections, eczema, and thrombocytopenia. The timing of onset with weaning and the absence of bleeding manifestations make this diagnosis unlikely.

Pediatric epidermolysis bullosa (Option C): While this condition causes skin fragility and blistering, it is present from birth and is not associated with weaning or diarrhea. The lesions in epidermolysis bullosa occur primarily at sites of mechanical trauma.

Atopic dermatitis (Option D): Although this can present in infancy, it is not associated with weaning or diarrhea.

questions.text: A subject reaches high altitude suddenly. Few days later, he was diagnosed as having cerebral edema. Identify the correct mechanism behind this pathophysiology.

choices.text: Low arterial PO₂ induced cerebral vasodilation
High arterial pH induced cerebral vasodilation
Low arterial PO₂ induced cerebral vasoconstriction
High arterial pH induced cerebral vasoconstriction

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Low arterial PO2 induced cerebral vasodilation

Explanation:

  • At high altitude, the drop in arterial PO₂ causes hypoxemia, prompting cerebral vasodilation to enhance oxygen delivery, but this response increases capillary pressure and permeability, leading to fluid leakage and resulting in cerebral edema.

High-Altitude Cerebral Edema (HACE)

Category

Details

Cause

Capillary leakage leads to brain swelling, often due to rapid ascent to high altitudes.

Symptoms

Severe headache, nausea, vomiting, ataxia (lack of coordination), disorientation, confusion, hallucinations, papilledema, and potentially coma due to herniation of the brain through tentorium.

Mechanism
  • Increased capillary pressure is caused by hypoxia-induced local vasodilation of cerebral blood vessels, leading to fluid leakage into brain tissues. (Option A)
  • Chemical factors like vascular endothelial growth factor and inflammatory cytokines may also increase endothelial permeability.

Onset

Typically within 8-24 hours after rapid ascent to high altitude; symptoms can progress quickly over the next 4-8 days if untreated.

Treatment
  • First Step - Immediate descent to a lower altitude
  • Administration of oxygen
  • High-dose dexamethasone to reduce cerebral edema and inflammation
  • Acetazolamide to promote acclimatization and reduce CSF formation.
  • Portable Hyperbaric Chamber: Symptoms will return when the patient leaves the chamber, but they may improve briefly, allowing the patient to help with evacuation.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - High arterial pH induced cerebral vasodilation: At high altitude, hyperventilation causes respiratory alkalosis (↑pH), which actually causes vasoconstriction, not vasodilation.

Option C - Low arterial PO₂ induced cerebral vasoconstriction: This is incorrect; low PO₂ causes vasodilation in the brain.

Option D - High arterial pH induced cerebral vasoconstriction: While true, this is not the primary mechanism for cerebral edema in high altitude. The edema is due to hypoxia-induced vasodilation, not alkalosis-induced vasoconstriction.
